It is exactly what it is. A little box for you to easily pop-in your laptop hard disk for connection to any USB system. I used it for two purposes: to move data quickly from my old laptop to my new (which happened to support USB 3.0, making quick work of a 200GB of data transfer). The rig itself is tight as a drum, once all screwed together, has a nice no-slip surface, and a cool blue flashing \\"activity\\" LED.

No complaints whatsoever.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
This is listed as an 8-cell battery, and may indeed contain 8-cells. However, it does not have the same high capacity that the manufacturer's (HP) 8-cell version has. It is comparable to the OEM 6-cell battery.

I immediately returned it when I realized this. The seller was very prompt in responding and took the return with very little hassle.

Please compare mAw/WH among batteries before purchasing! My original battery for my TX1020 has a stated capacity of 7365 mAH or 55Wh. The HP extended battery is 73Wh. The \\"extended\\" battery on this page is only 8800 mAh! That's only a life extension of 635mah for having 33% more cells. Huh?

After returning this I found a much better third party battery that had capacity (and construction!) more in line with the OEM extended version for about $45(US). The OEM version is built so that the cells are staggered and hang down below the unit, so that on a flat surface it is propped up for better ventilation than the 6-cell or \\"8-cell\\" on this page.

I recommend a battery with at least a capacity of 10,000 mAh instead of this battery.

In response to another review here, all of these batteries must be fully charged and discharged completely one full time before they are properly calibrated. The first charge will probably give really short life, and then perform properly after that. This is not explained anywhere, but is necessary.

Hope you find this review useful!

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
I used to always bottom out my Razer BlackWidow with MX Blues. I like the click and clack noises but I have a friend with the o rings and I really liked them, so I decided to buy them. It took a really long time to do all the keys, but man is it worth it. I'm getting used to the lack of a clack noise, but because they're MX blues, the keys themselves are still very tactile and clicky, I'm not really missing out on anything. It doesn't make the keys mushy or bad in any way. I'm really glad I got the red o rings because I swear the distance difference is actually pretty noticeable, I wouldn't get the blue o-rings unless you want super short key travel.

Note if you have a Razer BlackWidow (mine's a pre 2013 model), the +, enter, and 0 key on the numberpad have stabilizer bars that are facing the wrong way so they're damn near impossible to remove or put back. They unclip on the edge of the keyboard instead of toward the inside of the keyboard. I didn't bother with those keys since I really don't care about the number pad, although it's kind of irritating knowing that I couldn't get every single key. If you're super OCD just a forewarning.

Also, it takes a while to put these suckers on. Make sure you have a good key puller, I recommend WASD's key puller, although this is entirely up to your preference. Also, I wouldn't bother trying to put the o rings on with your fingers, even if you're really nimble. I took a pen and unscrewed the top and it fit perfectly to push on all the o rings. It took a while but if I tried to do it any other way I imagine it would've taken forever.

Even though the price is a little steep, as everyone else is saying, it's worth it. If you're even here looking at o rings for your mechanical keyboard, you know what you're doing and you know exactly what you want. Go for it.

EDIT after a few months of use:

So, today I was cleaning my mechanical keyboard and decided to take off the O-rings. I just bought another keyboard with ALPS switches that are very, very clicky and I wanted to go back to the original feel of regular MX blue switches while the ALPS keyboard is shipping. That isn't to say I entirely disliked the O-rings. I can see how they're awesome if you have a linear switch and you want to shorten your key travel distance. For that--they're perfect; and if you want a switch to be less noisy if you're in an office environment they would be great as well. However, over time, I missed the clack of the MX Blues. It's weirdly soothing.

I'm not saying anything bad about the product, as they did their job perfectly. I tried them and simply discovered I did miss the bottoming out noise, so I went back to normal. If you know for a fact you like your keyboards to be noisy, you will probably enjoy the difference this product makes for a while, just for the sake of change, then you might go back to wonderfully noisy switches. Just know what you're buying and really consider whether or not this would be right for you.st bought another keyboard with ALPS switches that are very, very clicky and I wanted to go back to the original feel of regular MX blue switches while the ALPS keyboard is shipping. That isn't to say I entirely disliked the O-rings. I can see how they're awesome if you have a linear switch and you want to shorten your key travel distance. For that--they're perfect; and if you want a switch to be less noisy if you're in an office environment they would be great as well. However, over time, I missed the clack of the MX Blues. It's weirdly soothing.

I'm not saying anything bad about the product, as they did their job perfectly. I tried them and simply discovered I did miss the bottoming out noise, so I went back to normal. If you know for a fact you like your keyboards to be noisy, you will probably enjoy the difference this product makes for a while, just for the sake of change, then you might go back to wonderfully noisy switches. Just know what you're buying and really consider whether or not this would be right for you.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
I've been wanting a Kindle for a long time, but living in the antipodes (New Zealand) was sure that the shipping would be a killer. However, the entire product (incl shipping) was just a little bit over $220NZD which made it definitely worth it.

I am a graduate student at university, and instead of carrying a giant binder full of paper, I can now carry my Kindle. As well as saving my back, I am saving a lot of trees! and printer ink!

I must admit, apart from the practical aspect of the Kindle, I've also become hooked on reading science fiction again, while conventional books are typically over $20, I can get a Kindleformat e-book for around a few dollars, and have expanded my library many times over in the month or so since I purchased the Kindle!

Finally, I was pleasantly surprised to find that there are GAMES on the Kindle... word of warning though, I've found that only the ones released by Amazon are any good, and there were a couple of other games (admittedly free games) which promised interactivity, but weren't really.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
I purchased this router a few days ago. I received V8.4 and googled around to see which DD-WRT build date would work. Apparently no one has tried any build date past July 2013, in fears of bricking it.

I decided I'd try the latest build from Dec 24, 2013, and it worked. Go to the DD-WRT website, then search the router database. Here's what you need:

12-24-2013-r23204 › tplink_tl-wr841ndv8 > factory-to-ddwrt.bin (If you're upgrading from the factory firmware, you only need the factory-to-ddwrt.bin file)

You can also flash back to factory firmware (I did so just for testing purposes). To do this, Google "Files for reverting from DD-WRT to STOCK FIRMWARE". Signup and download the file for TP-Link WR841N/ND v8.x

I uploaded a picture to Amazon showing the latest build.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
My Google Nexus 7 2013 purchased at Best Buy went back today. (The manufacture date on package said 2013 07) IT WAS EXTREMELY BUGGY! The response to the power button was sporadic. The unit would hang and become unresponsive and could not be shut down. Tech adviser said to hold the power button for 20 seconds, which didn't work. Finally after several rounds of holding the button for a count of 60 and beyond, the unit finally shut down.

It then would shut down randomly, all the way to the total reboot state rather than just the sleep state.

The touch screen was erratic and finicky, sometimes responding and sometimes not.

Upon return, the clerk said that he owns the same unit and it works perfectly, but that some of these devices are definitely duds. When I asked if they get a lot of returns of the Nexus 7, he said \\"some.\\" That said enough for me. I did a return rather than an exchange.

Wait for the manufacturer to figure this out and then be sure you're getting a freshly manufactured unit.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: If they had allowed me to give this product a MINUS 10 stars, that's what I would have given it.    We researched various tuners and bought this one. It was a disaster. The TV antenna has a very powerful magnet in the bottom. However, there is no mention on the package that a magnet is included or a warning not to get the antenna too close to your computer.     Unfortunately, I had my laptop in my lap as I was unpacking the unit. As I was unwrapping the antenna, the magnet attached itself to the palm rest on my laptop. I had to pull it off. My computer instantly went off and could not be rebooted. The magnet had totally erased all of the data from the hard drive. The hard drive had to be totally replaced. I called Pinnacle to tell them what happened. They said they would get back to me, and never did. I can't believe that they would create a product specifically for use with a computer and put a powerful magnet in it. Then they won't even take responsibility for the havoc it created.

WELL, SHE WAS RIGHT ... You insert your iPad into the case and you are in business, it's as simple as that. instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
Quality control on these cables is okay on the finish and fit HOWEVER not on length or matching end parts.

I ordered five of these cables from ValexOnline EXPECTING to receive five 12\\" C7 figure-eight power cables that all looked the same and were 12\\" long. What I received was five cables that were all different in length and had different plug end fittings. They were the right plug end type but were made by different companies so they all looked different.

Cable 1 is 21.75\\" long
Cable 2 is 21.25\\" long
Cable 3 is 20.50\\" long
Cable 4 is 20.00\\" long
Cable 5 is 19.75\\" long

So from the above measurements you can see that there is a 2\\" (2 inch) difference between the longest and shortest cable and the shortest cable is 7.75\\" longer than the advertised 1 ft (12 inch) cable being sold.

These cables are so close to 24\\" that they should be called 18\\" or 1.5 foot cables. Too long for what I needed and don't match so they look very odd in my project.

Amazon should really crack down on this sort of false advertising since now reading all the reviews I see the sizing issue is well documented. If anyone states that I should have checked this first before buying then my reply is why hasn't Amazon done something already instead of turning a blind eye.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
I have been a diehard PC fan since I got my first IBM 640MB RAM, two-floppy-drive PC back in 1981. But with the technological advances of the last few decades, it really is all about the operating system. And I have so had it with Microsoft. I've been clinging to XP, eschewing the poorly written Vista, and dreading MS's threatened loss of support for XP. But what I finally tired of is the constant parade of digital hobgoblins that haunt the OS of every PC - viruses, malware, resident update monitors, anti-virus software, etc. All of these things erode and destroy the operating performance of a PC.

I purchased this low-end Mac mini because it had the same processor as my PC - and it was cheap. I bought 4GB of Crucial memory, watched the video on YouTube, and effortlessly upgraded the memory to 4GB in about 15 minutes. It was not the easiest upgrade I have made - and I definitely do not recommend it to the novice. But I have been building my own PCs for years now. Incidentally, in upgrading my memory, I also allowed my nVidia graphics memory to bump up to 256MB - nice!

What first amazed me was how QUICKLY the Mac booted up, since my PC takes FOREVER to load all the crap that is necessary to work with the flawed Windows OS. The second thing that amazed me was how much FASTER this computer was than my old PC, despite it having the same CPU and memory (I should add that I routinely did hard drive and registry cleanups on my PC, so that was not why it was running so slowly). The third thing that amazed me was how intuitive and simple the Mac OS X GUI was to work with.

My only regret is that I did not upgrade the hard drive at the same time. However, I have a 1TB USB external that works with Time Machine (what a great background backup program!) and another 1TB Firewire800 external I use for data storage, so there is little pressure on the standard 120GB 5400rpm drive. However, I imagine I will - at some point - swap it out for at least a 500GB 7200rpm drive, which should boost performance even more.

If you are using this to switch from a PC, keep your old mouse or trackball, but definitely get the new Mac keyboard. It is a stunning piece of visual art in addition to being a highly functional, ergonomically superior keyed-entry device. It's just another [...].

If you have been thinking about a Mac and already have an LCD screen you like, give this great mini a try. You will always look with reverence on the day you severed the chains of your bondage with Redmond.h should boost performance even more. instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: I love every thing about my new Kindle, from the size and weight of it to the handsome design and incomparable readability. But had I known that Amazon does not allow library access to Kindles, which means no free rentals of e-books, I would have chosen another e-reader. Log on to your library's web site and see the long list of devices that CAN download e-book rentals, and you will be amazed that Kindle appears to be the only one that doesn't allow library access.     I have never been dissatisfied with Amazon's products or services, and have always had positive results from shopping on Amazon. So I can only hope that Amazon will see the disservice they are doing to their customers by forcing them to buy what they could otherwise rent for free. Perhaps if enough Kindle owners and even more important, would-be Kindle owners, were to protest, Amazon might rethink their position and be magnanimous enough to change their policy.    After all, libraries haven't put book-sellers out of business. Their free rentals of e-books may lose some e-book sales for Amazon, but they can also lead to more Kindle sales.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
Watch out for Fake product on this card even though they are sold by Amazon

I ordered one of these cards based on the good reviews on the product. Amazon shipping was prompt as always. The Card arrived in its original Asus packaging. The first thing that i noticed was that the package seemed to be sealed differently with a long tape instead of shrink wrap or circular seal. Another suspicious thing that was noticed was that there was a sticker over the UPC number. But the card seemed to be as described from its looks. I went ahead and installed it in the system and the first thing that was noticed was that the card does not install on the motherboard since the CPU fan was hitting against the BIOS battery. I then went ahead and reviewed the diagrams on the card and it looked like the heatsink was mounted incorrectly, so went ahead and remounted the heat sink turning it around 180 degrees and now it fits properly on the motherboard. Further all installations went smoothly and the system properly booted up.
So my thoughts at that point was that this was a quality control issue with ASUS. After installing Windows 8.1 everything seemed to be working fine. I then went ahead and installed the driver from ASUS and it seemed to go smoothly. The system asked for a reboot and now windows started complaining that the driver for the video card is outdated and wanted to update it, and this is when i noticed that the card detected was a 6670 instead of 7250 which is one generation older.
I then went to AMD site and downloaded the driver and even that was detecting the card as a 6670 instead of 7250. I decided to get more in-depth into this and started reviewing the card in detail and that is when i noticed that the card i received had a different mounting plate than what was given in the ASUS site and video outputs were all in the wrong places.
Called up Amazon and they agreed to send a replacement by next day air. So hoping that the replacement card that i get will not be a fake one again.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
It came in a small package for what I expected which only weighted 2 pounds. It brings a Keyboard and a stand of the iPad which doubles a protective case with a kickstand. I really liked the stand since it fits very snug and has all corners protected.

The keyboard is easy to use and has a LOT of features, I could use it vertically, horizontally, end even just sitting on a desk while I'm on the couch. The separable design was a clever feature, and very convenient. I luckily use a tray to put this while I'm in bed or watching tv, but if I didn't have that, I would see it being a problem having it on my lap.

The keyboard is almost the size of a full keyboard, but it's barely noticeable because of how it's laid out. Very soft on key press, and doesn't sound weird or noisy when I'm writing.

I would really recommend this product to anyone who needs to go on a trip and don't want to bring a laptop, but still has to do some writing. 5/5

All of this was done easily on the Keyboard from the iPad. :)

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
Having tested the initial Apple multi touch mouse I used it for about a week and found it to be utterly useless. It just feels wrong in the hand, poor tracking and I wasn't alone in that experience. Then I got the Arc Touch Mouse and instantly noticed how light it was. It felt like a mouse should and worked like a mouse but allows natural gestures through touch. Sure it isn't a full face multi touch (In fact, its not even multi) but it is a marriage between the two. Full multi touch is for touchscreens or track pads, Mice are mice and should blend the technology nicely.

I haven't used an ultra portable mouse to date that didn't feel too small in my hand or be too clunky. After 30 minutes I didn't know the difference other than the gestures.
I would rate this mouse very highly indeed. Well done Microsoft.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: I purchased 2 of these chips in February. In late March one of them went bad, which is not a huge issue. The chips come with a lifetime warranty.    The huge issue is that when I RMA'd the bad chip to Corsair (RMA #1099812) they refused to honor the warranty. I contacted customer support 8 times, each time I was told that a supervisor that could approve the RMA was not available and that they would call me back. I never received a return phone call and finally gave up.    I would highly recommend looking elsewhere for memory. When it comes down to it you can find the same product elsewhere and if it goes bad you won't have to worry about being stiffed on the warranty.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
This is one of the worst purchases I've ever made. 3 months after buying the machine, I'm also running into an overheating problem. I've sprayed out the fan with a dust blower, but the laptop is shutting down after 2 hours of use and won't reboot until it's completely cooled off.

Customer support was blocked by a combination of bad instructions and a voice recognition system telling me that I was out of warranty. Trying to get a human was mostly useless until 3 days later, I accidentally stumbled on a way to get a human. (Keep telling the voice recognition system that the serial number is wrong and you will get a human.)

Now they want my laptop for 7-10 business days and based on other reviews it seems the likelihood that it will be truly fixed is slim.

Sony tech support denies any knowledge of an overheating problem. Please don't buy Sony until these problems are resolved.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
Do no buy this tablet. I bought this for my family for Christmas, in particular for my 17-month old daughter. For the first week it was great, serve its purpose. However, it is now acting up. The charger has to be pushed in for it to get a charge (I've never forced the charger in it, and I know for sure my daughter hasn't messed with it). The touch screen isn't really a touch screen. More like a push screen where it takes forever for something to highlight to write in the text box. My daughter can't play with her games because it won't react with her finger. When reading a book, the pages won't turn until several swipes. Also, the Amazon Prime for Kindle with the Kindle lending library only works with the Kindle's.

So here is my experience with this piece of crap. Just don't be cheap (even for your children) and buy the real thing-Kindle or an Ipad. I know it's super expensive and people (like me) buy this to stay on the cheap side of life. But this is just wasting your money. Just go out and shed of few hundred dollars (we do already on our phones) for something that really works and is a touch screen with no lagging.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
The 12-cell battery obtained from EPC failed suddenly shortly after purchase. EPC initially and rightly offered to replace it and issued an RMA. After returning the 12-cell battery I received (eventually, and after prodding) only a 6-cell battery. When I pointed out the error EPC did not offer to swap the 6-cell with a 12 -- instead they said they would repair the original 12-cell ...but at an additional cost to me. After I complained EPC eventually issued a partial refund, but I was still out over $25 (including my return shipping cost, which they also offered to refund but never did).
In short: EPC failed to do what they originally said they would (swap the defective battery for another one) and appeared to drag out the process hoping I would get discouraged and, well, give up. I certainly gave EPC every chance to make things right. Never an address, phone number or other avenue given for redress. Stay away from EPC. Signed, Ripped-Off.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
Dishonesty in the drivers ruins the whole thing.

I got this today and installed it. The board is OK so far but the driver disk started by trying to con me into installing Chrome and the Google toolbar as well as Norton. I paid good money for this board and expect the driver disk to contain drivers not their cheap attempt at making a few nickles on the side.

If I was downloading freeware I would understand their need for third party financing but this was not it. I paid real dollars and the first thing on their disk was Chrome. Next was the Google Toolbar. The third was Norton. ASUS seems to be running an ad agency instead of selling motherboards. Or maybe it is AMD. Both of them are permanently off my list from today.

It is a sad commentary on our society when at every turn you have to deal with deception. It is also very disappointing that Google would try to push Chrome which is a fine browser like this. One day I try to find Chrome for my Linux without success and next day I have to worry having it forced on me.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
I have a "modern" computer and I had installed the correct drivers, software, etc .... but I received the BSOD every time I clicked on EZ Grabber. I tried using other video programs but I had issues with them using the VC500 especially NO AUDIO. I spent several days researching the issue and it seems to come up with this product especially the No AUDIO.

I installed it on another computer and I was able to get the EZ Grabber to capture the audio correctly once I selected "dvd" and not avi and I was going to try other video format options but I ended up getting the BSOD the next day when I went to use it again.

Therefore, it worked ONCE for me on this other computer before giving me the BSOD repeatedly.

After reading a few things I decided to get the Dazzle * DVD Recorder HD which installed easily and has worked right from the start for me. I mainly wanted to save old family VHS tapes to my computer so I can edit them and give them out at XMAS.

I want to also include a few details which "might" be the cause of the issue:

This capture card was BRAND NEW but it was purchased many, many, years ago and never opened so there could be something different about this one than the current ones (they look identical and the hardware/components should not have changed inside). Also, the Dazzle device comes with the current Pinnacle software and it worked right off where as the VC500 came with old drivers and outdated software (it would have been current when I purchased it years ago) but I downloaded the current drivers and I installed some current video software.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: I am a card carrying AMD, ASUS and Corsair hardware enthusiast.  This latest model of the Corsair Hydro H60 is remarkable!  I had the original version and it lasted me 5 years working smoothy to keep my CPU cool, always in 30C's idle and loaded at 45 to 48C's.  This new one is so much quieter and is keeping the temperatures in the 30C's ad idle and in the 40C's fully loaded as well. So what's the difference between old and new Hydro H60?  I can run the fan on Turbo setting which is quieter than the older Standard speed (I like quiet).  Plus - a big plus. The bracket for AM sockets, in my case AM3 and AM3+ is so easy to install compared to the older model.  All you need do is put the bracket over the top of the Cooler and a magnetic attachment holds it in place while you tighten the fasteners by hand until the cooler is snug on the processor. Nothing more to do for us AMD enthusiasts.  The AM sockets have the two catches for the regular fans to fit over then tighten up.  The same catches are all you need for the Hydro H60 bracket for snugging up the cooler to the processor.  Outstanding Corsair!!  I have Corsair Looped Cooling in two rigs and Corsair Memory and Corsair PSU.  Yep, big fan of Corsair.  Kudos for upgrading the H60 to take on moderate to extreme overclocking with the Athlon, Phenom and FX series processors. Other upgrades to the H60. Impressive larger hoses and a much sturdier built cooler/pump module.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: This is a truly remarkable device - a mouse and fully functional keyboard combined, that sits flat on my desk along with all my other papers and books (try that with a traditional keyboard and mouse - its not easy).  The TouchStream takes up little space, is lightningly fast and accurate, and folds up to sit neatly next to my iMac when i don't use it.   As with anything worth the effort, one needs to spend some time learning how to use it - one even does it with a car or a bicycle, and even a pen, so why not with a keyboard.  I have the QWERTY version, but type Dvorak and have also activated the mouse on the left hand side of the device.  I'ts endlessly configurable to suit just what you want.   I have a TouchStream at home and now want another to use another at work - but FingerWorks are now not operating any more, so i'm hoping to get one second hand.  It's beyond me why anyone would use a clunky keyboard and a separate erratic mouse (as most are) when something so remarkable is available, or rather, was available.  Is there not some other manufacurer that wants to take up making these keyboards?

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
I added 8GB (2x4GB) RAM and 240GB SSD to this, installed 8.1 Pro with Media Center, and I'm using it to view live TV and to record TV shows from a HDHomeRun Prime using a FiOS M-Card.

Thoughts:
- This is a great value for the price. You should shop around as it is currently on promotion elsewhere.
- Able to record 2 shows simultaneously while I watch live TV
- No playback stuttering regardless of the file format I throw at it
- Surprisingly quiet, even when fully loaded
- 8GB was overkill as however hard I push it, it doesn't use more than 2GB RAM. I would recommend 4GB (2x2GB) instead
- Installation is very easy and tool-less given the use of thumbscrews
- I initially loaded all the drivers that Zotac has on their site. Windows update suggested I upgrade the Intel graphics driver, which I did. But there were too many stuttering issues. I ended up rolling back to the older version provided by Zotac and its working great again.
- Card reader is a great option for immediately reviewing photos after an event
- Works well with my SONOS surround system (DD Plus)

Cons:
- No IR receiver or Wifi. I use LAN with Gigabit switches anyway, but I did end up buying an external IR receiver
- Glossy curved two-tone black and white finish. Its an outdated look. A Matte, boxy finish with flat surfaces would have been much better and would have gone well with the rest of my equipment.
- Has a laptop style power brick. This could have been smaller given its incapable of using more than 30W.

Overall, this is a great value for the performance you get for a HTPC.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
I bought this product cause I was told it was good. However, since the first day I've had issues with it disconnecting. First week it would disconnect on and off for 20 minutes at a time every couple of hours or so. Over time it \\"got better\\" and would disconnect 4 or 5 times a month along with having issues reconnecting after resetting it multiple times. I've had it for 4 months now and I'm looking at getting a new router. I just wish I could get my money back cause this whole product is garbage. But I blame myself for not returning the minute the brand new product gave me issues.

And the software Netgear Genie that comes with it also is useless cause it inaccurately tells me what is going on. It'll tell the internet is connected when it's not. Even more annoying is that when the internet is actually connecting to our wireless devices and laptops, it will constantly tell me it's not and that the wireless is down. Also it doesn't really assist you in anyway to figure out the problems of it constantly disconnecting.

This whole product is garbage and every forum online of people having the same issues I'm having are told that basic functions of the router may be causing the disconnect. Apparently turning off your security system will help keep it connected. Well that's great Netgear, I'm glad giving all my neighbors access to my internet will help my useless router work better!

You'll get better wireless stealing Starbucks free wifi 3 miles down the road. Don't bother with this junk, Netgear clearly doesn't put enough time into their products. I will never buy another Netgear product!

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: I have read a lot of the reviews and appreciate the input.  It seems to me the DX and possibly the K2 are still just a bit \\"too new\\" and untested to invest this amount of money.  I love the concept and it seems the Kindle is a reasonably nice product.  However, things I have picked up from the reviews which tell me to wait for a year or two are:    1.  Price.  This is still a bit too expensive to feel comfortable that I am getting my money's worth.  Amazon should do what the ink-jet printer folks did which is give you the printer for almost nothing and you pay big on the refills -- give the Kindle away for almost nothing and make the money on the downloads.  This will get millions of Kindles out on the market creating a lot more demand for content.    2.  It appears the DX (and maybe the K2?) screen will likely break or get scratched even under fairly normal use - really bad design by Amazon and the current policy is to charge you $350 to get it fixed.    2. The other big issue is the battery.  If I understand correctly, you cannot buy a replacement battery, you have to turn your Kindle in for over $100 or more to have them ship you a new Kindle (so why can't they ship you a new Kindle if you screen breaks for the same price?)  This means that about every two years (average time for batteries to work for a long period of time) you are paying over $100 to keep your kindle working.    3. If you upgrade to the next Kindle, you have a good chance of losing books you previously bought that Amazon claims is \\"safe forever\\".    4. Amazon seems to believe they are the morality police and will delete whatever they feel is inappropriate on your Kindle - really bad policy.    5. I think having some kind of built-in led light would be useful to make it readable at night or while in a car or similar.  This would be a small drain on the battery, but very useful.    I think this space needs a really strong competitor to motivate Amazon to \\"do this right\\".  I don't see this taking off until there is a strong competitor and these core issues addressed.    Dale

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: Is there a 4.5 stars?  This is no Apple but it's pretty darn good for the price.  Display is better than the iPad Mini.  Android is versatile.  But..there is less fluidity than the mini.  Most people would never know it.  It has (I think) to do with the ballistics in dragging and scrolling.  I like the form factor BETTER than the iPad mini.  And this is much easier to hold onto because of the rubberish back and size.  AND it has wireless charging which if you haven't tried you should.  That was a make or break for me.  It is absolutely buttonless on the front..a big plus.  And the apps are getting better but admittedly the mini has better apps.  I got the one without the data plan and haven't missed it.  You probably can use your cell phone for a wifi hot point if you really need it.  Or get one of Verizon's Jetpak so 10 of you can share a 4G connection via your WIFI.  I'd buy again for sure.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: Hey guys and gals.  Okay, I've had this machine for a week now.  I will probably update this after more time has passed.  I also like the small keyboard because there's less hand and finger travel involved so I find it much easier to type.      THE BATTERY is UNREAL.  READ your manuals boys and girls, ESPECIALLY the part about conditioning your battery three times.  Search the internet and download the free program \\"CPUID Hardware Monitor\\".  It shows the \\"wear level\\" and capacity of your battery.  VERY cool.  My battery started with 10% wear level out of the box.  After 3 \\"conditionings\\" as explained in the manual, I have zero wear level and today my power meter says I have 11 hours and 48 minutes to go!  Each \\"conditioning\\" I did, I watched the battery's capacity level in CPUID go up!  I have NEVER seen ANYTHING like this in my life and I have had multiple laptops since 1995.  The battery life is CRAZY.  Obviously those numbers will go down faster as you start and run programs.      I wish they could put decent graphic cards in these netbooks.  NONE of them in this price range on the market have one.  But then that would also kill the battery life as well.  This one will get you by with BASIC graphics handling.  I can watch HD video MP4s only with Quicktime.  VLC Media Player and Windows Media Player (after installing codecs for it) jitter and stutter with HD MP4 videos, Quicktime does NOT.  I have run several BASIC games, Hoyle Casino 2008, MS Pinball Arcade, Virtual Pool 3 and they all seem to run good, no issues.  As you have no T&L or anti-aliasing capabilities with this video card, the heavy duty 3D games stutter and jitter if they run AT ALL.  After a couple days I upgraded the RAM to 2 GB to see if that would help and it did not.  Basic, low graphic games run just fine.  What's funny is I watched HD video on YouTube with zero issues.  I run an older version of Adobe Photoshop without any issues.  Microsoft Office 2007 runs beautifully.    UPDATE: HD VIDEO EDITING  My Sanyo VPC CG10 HD digital camcorder creates videos in HD MP4 format.  I had to do a few things to get this computer to work with them.  I had to install the codecs from shark007.net to get the PC to work with the MP4s. After that, they will play in Windows Media Player as well.  HD editing? I bought the \\"Wondershare\\" Netbook converter suite which includes their \\"DVD to netbook converter\\" and a pretty quick and efficient \\"Video to netbook\\" converter. They have a trial and that's what made me buy it. It's simple, fast, efficient, has many options and takes up very little space on my hard drive. Google them. After trying several other converters, I found this to be the best for me. I convert the videos from MP4 to WMV and load them into the old XP Windows Movie Maker. I found out that XP Windows Movie Maker uses profiles. The default settings don't allow you to save your creations in HD format. HOWEVER, I found dozens of *.prx files, which are the profiles, all over the web. I downloaded several HD profiles. Some included instructions on which folder to copy them to. WALLA! Like magic... I am now editing and saving HD videos with this netbook using Windows XP SP3 and the old XP Windows Movie Maker on a 1.66 Ghz processor, 2 gigs of RAM! No stuttering, no issues, zero problems and the videos come out great!    UPDATE: SEE COMMENTS BELOW ON MY RAM MEMORY EXPERIENCE!    Overall speed.  This thing flies!!!  Clicking on things, opening programs, Windows start up... zooming in a map in Delorme or Microsoft mapping software... ALL wayyyyyyy faster than my 2.2 Ghz Dual Core, 4 GB RAM Windows 7 Professional laptop.  How does THAT happen???  Everything just seems to happen FASTER.  Is it Windows XP?  I don't know but I did WANT a netbook with Windows XP.  I wanted one before you can't buy them any longer.  As it is now, you can't buy them in stores any longer.    Overall, for $300, I LOVE this little machine and have decided I will keep it.  I'll save the HD video editing for my other laptop.  Although, I have not tried it yet on this little machine. I anticipate this little machine will be going with me everywhere I go... never leave the house without it!    I give it 5 stars out of 5!!!  It's a keeper!!!    Juan

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
Update July 4, 2013:
I've been meaning to update, but hadn't gotten around to it until now. By February 2013, the battery held no charge and started to swell (just as the original had after 4 years of use.) Again, I would not buy this again knowing what I know now.

Update for Dec 13, 2012: The battery turned out to be a piece of junk. It started to go downhill after 2 months, and now only holds a 15 minute charge with no warning that it is low. The computer just turns off. I would recommend against purchasing this battery, even at a cheap price.

[previous review]
First of all, the finish doesn't match the actual MacBook, as the black MacBook is matte, and the battery is shiny. That's not a problem, since I have a leather cover for my computer. I \\"trained\\" the battery for over 2 weeks, completely emptying it each time, and it still doesn't keep very accurate time. Again I can make do, but it's something to be aware of. When it gets to about 20 minutes to go, you better either plug in or start saving everything that you don't want to lose.

I read a few reviews where people are claiming 4 hours on a charge. I wasn't so lucky. On the lowest screen brightness setting, I can probably get about 2.5 hours out of one charge. I have had the battery for about a month now, so yeah, that's as good as it's ever going to be with this one. My original MacBook battery wasn't much better, so at least this one is cheap. If it dies on me anytime soon, as in stops holding a charge, I'll update this review. If you don't see anything below, my battery is still functioning the way it should.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input:
For those of us who grew up with FM receivers the size of a PC, this is a revelation. The radio looks more like an antenna than an FM Stereo tuner. A good deal of the compact size comes from the fact that all of the amplification is located in your PC or your powered speakers. The cables need to be hooked up to a USB port, as well as either a Line-In or Mic-In connector on your sound card. I can't find fault with the hardware, but the software has been a nightmare.
I've installed the radio on two Windows 98 machines and a Windows 2000 Professional machine with miserable results. I was never able to get on-screen volume controls to work under Windows 98, and after several weeks all of the software quit working entirely. Under windows 2000 Pro, everything worked O.K. for a couple of months, then I started getting an error message on start up that said that a number must be between 1 and (about 2 billion). All of the station names disappeared, and the volume controls in the D-Link software stopped working. Upgrading to new drivers resulted in the software being unable to locate the radio, even though Windows said that it was there and working correctly. Uninstalling the software still resulted in Windows trying to start it on boot up. Reinstalling the software was unsuccessful, as I kept receiving the 'unable to locate radio' message.
So, now I'm left with a [dollar amount] paperweight. Perhaps this is the reason that you don't see a lot of USB radios on the market. While it is a great concept, the software is definitely \\"not ready for prime time\\". If you really need to integrate a radio into your PC, you should probably look elsewhere.

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: Samsung sent me this monitor to replace a syncmaster 225bw since they did not have any in stock to replace it.     First of all, the stand is awful. It's a round egg-shaped thing that fits into the monitor, but the force that's required to put it in can certainly damage the monitor. I was never able to get it in for over a month. Samsung tech support was not helpful about it and claimed that the stand issue was my problem.   I read on some obscure forum that some guy got his to fit by having it upside down on his bed as he forced it in by putting all his body weight into it. I tried it and it popped in. I finally was able to use it.     Fast forward 3 months later, the monitor just went to a black screen and no matter what I tried, it won't show anything other than black. I rma'd the monitor, shipped it back. they claimed they did a repair on it and shipped it back. I open the box to find the same issue. I swear all they did was wait a week, put it back in another box and shipped it back. I did another rma, shipped it to them, they claimed they did a repair and sent it back, same issue.     I am currently on hold with \\"customer relations department\\" to get them to just issue me a replacement. I've been on hold for 40 minutes now and still counting.     At this point, I would just say that samsung has gotten too big for their own good. I used to love their products, but now I wouldn't recommend any of their products to anyone. It's a good thing I waited on buying that samsung hdtv a few weeks ago...     EDIT: a follow up on this review - I was placed on hold with their customer relations department, they finally picked up around 6:50. I told her exactly what happened with this monitor, and how many times it was sent for repairs with no results. She said she will send another monitor and when I receive it, I can send back my old one. I said no problem, and she put me on hold. After about 5 minutes on hold, the phone hangs up. I tried to call back only to have the customer support person tell me that customer relations is closed now. After some arguing, he issued the exchange.     Today my monitor shipped and it's at home. I am just Hoping that Samsung ran out of 2233BW's and shipped me a better monitor...

instruction: Given an Amazon review, indicate whether it is a 'Positive Review' or 'Negative Review'.
input: I'm not very tech savvy, but I really like this laptop. It does everything I need it to do, has a excellent battery life, seems to be very fast. It has a touchscreen and a backlit keyboard, so those are two very nice touches, especially in this price range. I had heard a lot of complaints about Windows 8, while I was researching a new computer, but to me, it does not seem like a big deal at all. There isn't any software to speak of on this machine, which is good, IMO. I haven't had this laptop that long, but I really have nothing negative to say about it. I would recommend it to anyone.
